page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces

rev.diff:
Line 206: Line 206:
==November==
==November==
â
{{main|November 2011 Tahrir clashes}}
 
[[File:Voa arrott egypt protest 230 20Nov11-resized.jpg|left|frame|Man injured in clashes between Egyptian police and protesters angry at army's continuing political influence in Cairo, November 20, 2011.]]
[[File:Voa arrott egypt protest 230 20Nov11-resized.jpg|left|frame|Man injured in clashes between Egyptian police and protesters angry at army's continuing political influence in Cairo, November 20, 2011.]]
â
{{Cleanup-rewrite|2=section|date=November 2011}}
+
â
On 19 November two people were killed and 600 wounded in violent clashes after mass protests in Tahrir Square against the military junta regime. The protests started in reaction to the military unilaterally announcing a super-constitution that representatives elected for writing the constitution will not be able change.
+
In November 2011, dissatisfied with the progress of the reforms, almost all civilian political parties called for an accelerated end to the military rule before drafting a constitution â either an immediate handover to a civilian-led government, or a turnover to the lower house of Parliament when it is seated in April, or after a presidential election, which would be scheduled as soon as possible. However, the parties remained deeply divided over what sort of civilian government should succeed the military: the Liberals and Islamists battled each other over the question of what rules should be imposed by the military for the selection of a constitutional convention.<ref name=NYT_Nov2011>{{cite web|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/22/world/middleeast/facing-calls-to-give-up-power-egypts-military-battles-crowds.html?partner=rss&emc=rss&src=igw |title=Egyptâs Civilian Government Submits Offer to Resign |publisher=New York Times |date=21 November 2011 |accessdate=21 November 2011}}</ref>
The protesters are demanding the SCAF to step down from governing and politics, and hand over the authority to civilians. Other demands include banning members of former [[Hosni Mubarak]] regime from running in the next election, and rejection of the military's super-constitution (which restricts the power of the future elected representative in writing the new constitution and removes the possibility of [[civilian control of the military]] and Egypt's foreign policy which will allow the military to act as a [[state within a state]] in Egypt, a system similar to Turkey's [[Deep State]] before democratic reforms).
The protesters are demanding the SCAF to step down from governing and politics, and hand over the authority to civilians. Other demands include banning members of former [[Hosni Mubarak]] regime from running in the next election, and rejection of the military's super-constitution (which restricts the power of the future elected representative in writing the new constitution and removes the possibility of [[civilian control of the military]] and Egypt's foreign policy which will allow the military to act as a [[state within a state]] in Egypt, a system similar to Turkey's [[Deep State]] before democratic reforms).
  +   +
On 19 November two people were killed and 600 wounded in violent clashes after mass protests in Tahrir Square against the military junta regime. The protests started in reaction to the military unilaterally announcing a super-constitution that representatives elected for writing the constitution will not be able change.
Egyptian medics say a police and army assault on anti-government protesters in Cairo has killed at least three people, raising the death toll in Egypt to at least five killed in two days of unrest. Police in Cairo lobbed teargas into crowds of protesters angry at the military governmentâs continued role in political life. Demonstrators kept control of Tahrir Square Sunday morning, and vowed to keep their revolution alive. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/Police-Protesters-Keep-up-Clashes-in-Cairo-134200628.html |title=Police, Protesters Keep up Clashes in Cairo |publisher=Voanews.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-20}} Public domain text from the article quoted</ref>
Egyptian medics say a police and army assault on anti-government protesters in Cairo has killed at least three people, raising the death toll in Egypt to at least five killed in two days of unrest. Police in Cairo lobbed teargas into crowds of protesters angry at the military governmentâs continued role in political life. Demonstrators kept control of Tahrir Square Sunday morning, and vowed to keep their revolution alive. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/Police-Protesters-Keep-up-Clashes-in-Cairo-134200628.html |title=Police, Protesters Keep up Clashes in Cairo |publisher=Voanews.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-20}} Public domain text from the article quoted</ref>
â
On Monday, November 21st - the third day of violence, the death toll of the Tahrir square clashes had risen to 22, with hundreds wounded.<ref>[http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/11/21/178303.html]</ref>
+
Protesters demanding faster reforms and establishment of civilian government took to the Tahrir square in Cairo, and also in other cities, and clashed with the security forces. On 21 November 2011, after several days of violent demonstrations in which more than 33 protesters lost their lives<ref>[http://www.democracynow.org/2011/11/22/egyptian_revolution_enters_new_phase_as Egyptian Revolution Enters New Phase] 22 November 2011 [[Democracy Now!]]</ref> and over 1,500 were wounded, the provisional government offered its resignation to the supreme military council in reaction to the use of force against the protesters.<ref name=NYT_Nov2011 />
  +   +
At a crisis meeting on 22 November 2011 between the political and the military leaders, the parties agreed for a new interim government to be formed, and to proceed with the scheduled parliamentary election on November 28, with a goal of holding a presidential election before the end of June 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/africa/Egyptian-Military-Agrees-to-Form-New-Government-134331228.html |title=Egypt to Form New Government, Military to Transfer Power |publisher=Voice of America |date=22 November 2011 |accessdate=22 November 2011}}</ref> Also on the same day, the US State Department condemned the excessive use of force against the demonstrators by the Egyptian security forces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/campaigns/us-steps-up-criticism-of-egypts-leaders-says-civilians-must-be-given-power/2011/11/22/gIQAShaulN_story.html |title=US steps up criticism of Egyptâs leaders, says civilians must be given power |publisher=The Washington Post |date=22 November 2011 |accessdate=22 November 2011}}</ref>
  +
{{clear}}
{{clear}}
